snippet.textDisplay:
7:10:00 The "verbose" script was a decision made by the English remaster team. Neither the Japanese version nor the original Playstation English version was like this. It was more of a pointed, impassioned drama with a tone similar to The Brothers Karamazov. Lines were sharp and packed punch. The English version had the downside of muddling some of the plot concepts with translation mistakes, but the dialogue itself was for the most part vastly more effective and human.

This translation drained the life out of it. It's an attempt to do a similar kind of translation as the third game set in Ivalice, Vagrant Story - which is a high bar for language and writing - but that script was translated and written by an absolute master, Alexander O. Smith. This is a pale imitation of his style marred by hack sensibilities, often converting simple statements into a line ten times the word count as the original text, employing lazy proverbs and dressing each line up in needless fluff.

While it has a few good moments, it's a massive diminishment of the story of Final Fantasy Tactics - this is coming from an enthusiast for opera, theater, and 19th century novels. I'm the target audience for this, and I consider it a huge failure.

It still blows my mind that this guy endured several thousand times the amount of this same kind of stuff throughout Final Fantasy 14, and then couldn't even feign basic respect for a much better story translated in the same style

snippet.textDisplay: People commenting on these FFT videos need to get a grip. Its Preach. You know how hes going to play these games. Whining in youtube comments that he will never read is just sad. He didn't play the way you wanted. Get over it.

snippet.textDisplay:
Yeah, I’m in the same boat as a lot of others folks are - this was a terrible play through by Preach. 

Whining about the game over mistakes he made. Complaining about the story he talks and skips over. 

It’s a shame that such a great game got treated this way.

snippet.textDisplay:
There's too many comments to point out in this video, and I'm at the point of exhaustion with it. This game, and games like it are specifically built around varying levels of grinding to unlock stuff, improve jobs, and test things out. I love your content man, but if you're incapable of being flexible for a game like this that needs some amount of grinding, then please don't play it. A lot of people who watched said this in some form, none of the issues you had are inherently the game's fault, the story isn't the game's fault (albeit vomiting people and places can get confusing, it's not perfect), the issues you had were of your own making and I know you're smart enough to see that after some reflection. 

If you're not willing to find a middle ground with grinding, then please don't try any other tactics/tactical rpg, because it's been one of the worst playthroughs of yours that I've watched in over a decade.

If you're not willing to find a middle ground with grinding, then please don't try any other tactics/tactical rpg, because it's been one of the worst playthroughs of yours that I've watched in over a decade.

snippet.textDisplay:
​​@Preachgaming 

7:09:38

I understand not liking the mid-battle dialogue because I personally think it can be such a drag especially when you have to follow the VA's pace

But how can you say you don't like the way the story is being told when you didn't even pay attention 90% of the time when it is being told. To go as far as to boil it down to "Verbose" just to pull something out of your ass to critique against a story you barely gave a fair shot of understanding is beyond baffling.

Evidently because:

You talk over the cutsecenes to chat about WoW or some other bs or get distracted by fart donos. 

Time and time again throughout the whole playthrough whenever story beats are on the screen, your attention span just drops to -3 like for example, the game literally states that the nation is at a Civil War and not even an hour later into the game you're like "we're at war?"


You cannot be serious.
